Dig. 40. 12. 20. 3 ‘ obligatum accipere debemus», qui exceptione se tueri non potest; ceterum si potest, dicendum non esse obligatum! Those exceptions which have only the weaker effect, though they prevent the creditor from succeeding in an action, yet leave the obligatio subsisting naturaliter, with all or most of the incidents which characterise such relations (Excursus V infi). As a general rule every exceptio will have the stronger efficacy is based upon the ius gentium and natural equity: ‘ desinit debitor esse is, qui nactus est exceptionem iustam nec ab aequitate naturali abhorrentem’ Dig. 50. 17. 66.

Thus the distinction between extinction ipso iure, and invalidation ope exceptionis, is not one of degree, sor some exceptions produce an effect undistinguishable from extinction ; it consists in the mode of their operation. A right extinguished ipso iure can never recover its vitality; but, given an event which operates only ope exceptioniS‚ i.e. confers a countervailing right on the debtor, the obligatio still subsists‚ and should the debtor’s· right be itself destroyed, will once more become enforceable, and recover its original value. In the first case only a new right can come into existence, which implies that all the conditions ordinarily required for the creation of an obligation must be satisfied, so that a mere renunciation by the debtor os the benefit which has accrued to him in the destruction of the creditor's right wiu not reestablish the creditor in statu quo unless such renunciation suffices in the particular case for the creation of an obligati03 ‘si pactum conventum tale suerit, quod actionem [ipso iure] tolleret, velut iniuriarum, non poterit, postea pacis· cendo ut agere possit, agere, quia et prima actio sublata est, et posterius

But in the second case it would be otherwise; the old right is not destroyed, but only balanced by a colliding or countervailing right in the debtor ; and if the latter right is in any way extinguished, even by mere waiver, the former will recover all its original force : ‘ pactus ne peteret, postea con- venit ut peteret.
